section: What is a data management plan?
text:
What is a data management plan?
A research data management plan (DMP)

is a living document


can be updated at any point, as required

title: How to write a research data management plan
section: What is a data management plan?
text:
What is a data management plan?
A DMP will outline all the stages of a project’s data lifecycle before data collection begins

how the data will be collected,
stored,
protected,
shared,
licensing rights to the data

title: How to write a research data management plan
section: Why write a data management plan?
text:
Why write a data management plan?
Personal reasons

Helps:

Formalise a process
Assess what is needed
Identify areas that require attention
Enforce consistency in data management

Being consistent with your data management will lead to fast retrieval


Adapt a pre-existing DMP for a similar project
Refer to the DMP when writing your thesis
Guide the project management of your project ⇛ timely thesis completion

title: Open Research in Practice
text:
Definition

A set of principles and practices in publicly funded research that make it more trasparent, accessible, inclusive, and collaborative, ensuring that research is freely available, under terms that enable attribution, reuse, redistribution and reproduction of the research and its underlying data and methods. [1], [2]

title: Open Research in Practice
text:
Not only publishing

title: Open Research in Practice
section: What can you do right now?
text:
What can you do right now?

Register for ORCiD
Share your presentations openly

You can do this on Zenodo
Or any repository (this particular presentation is hosted on GitHub)

Add a license to your presentation!

You can do this using the:

Creative Commons License Chooser https://chooser-beta.creativecommons.org/
Within Zenodo if you choose that route

So that people can reuse and cite your work

title: Open Research in Practice
section: What can you do right now?
text:
What can you do right now?

Share your code and scripts on GitHub (with appropriate reuse licensing)

With accessible and rich documentation (or just good enough so that anyone can understand!)

They might just help someone else
Need help choosing a software license?

https://choosealicense.com/

title: Open Research in Practice
section: What can you do right now?
text:
What can you do right now?

Have a paper published closed access?

Never too late to share the Author Accepted Manuscript on a public repository. Like:

Zenodo (general purpose)
Figshare (general purpose)
ResearchGate
Check whether the journal you are publishing in has a pre-print to support Green Open Access

And do not forget Creative Commons Licensing!
